message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger’s disease. The non-blanching raised erythematous papules on the lower extremities are consistent with palpable purpura, a classic finding in IgA nephropathy. The ultrasound findings suggest bowel involvement, as this disease can sometimes involve the gut. P-ANCA vasculitis and Gram-negative cocci infection are less likely to have these findings, while microthrombi occluding the vasculature is more consistent with thrombotic microangiopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest the patient has Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), which is characterized by palpable purpura, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal involvement. The ultrasonography findings of alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands suggest bowel edema, a common finding in HSP. The deposition of IgA immune complexes causes the inflammation and damage in HSP. Option A is incorrect because P-ANCA vasculitis affects medium-sized vessels, not small vessels like in HSP. Option B is incorrect because microthrombi do not cause dysmorphic RBCs and proteinuria, which are seen in HSP. Option C is incorrect because there is no evidence of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP), which is characterized by non-blanching raised erythematous papules, abdominal pain and vomiting, joint pain, and glomerulonephritis. The positive fecal occult blood test suggests gastrointestinal involvement. IgA immune complexes are deposited in the small vessels leading to vasculitis, which can explain the ultrasound findings. P-ANCA vasculitis involves larger vessels and is less likely to present in children. Microthrombi and gram-negative cocci infection are less likely based on the laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest Henoch-Schonlein purpura, which is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the small vessels. The ultrasonography findings also support the diagnosis. The other options do not fit the clinical picture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, non-blanching raised erythematous papules, and swollen/tender ankles, suggest Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP). The RBC with dysmorphic features, positive stool occult blood, and echogenic and hypoechogenic bands in the bowels on ultrasound also support this diagnosis. HSP is caused by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in small vessels. Options A and C do not fit with the clinical presentation, and option B may fit with the symptoms but is not the underlying cause of the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of sore throat, non-blanching raised erythematous papules, and limited range of motion in both ankles, which are signs and symptoms of IgA nephropathy. The positive stool test for occult blood may be a sign of gastrointestinal involvement, and the ultrasound findings are consistent with IgA nephropathy. The other options do not fit the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Henoch-Schonlein purpura, which is characterized by deposition of IgA immune complexes in small vessels. Alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands on ultrasonography are also consistent with this diagnosis. The other options are not associated with these specific symptoms and findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of abdominal pain and vomiting, as well as joint pain and a rash, which suggest a systemic disorder. The positive stool test for occult blood and the presence of dysmorphic RBCs in the urine suggest glomerulonephritis. The ultrasonography findings of alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands suggest mesenteric vasculitis or ischemia. The presence of IgA immune complex deposition is consistent with Henoch-Schonlein purpura, a systemic vasculitis that affects small vessels including the mesenteric vessels. Thus, (D) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of non-blanching raised erythematous papules, joint pain, and positive stool for occult blood, along with dysmorphic RBCs and IgA deposition, suggests the most likely cause is IgA immune complex deposition, indicating Henoch-Schonlein purpura. Microthrombi would have showed up in the laboratory studies and ultrasound as well, but it did not. Gram-negative cocci infection would have presented with different symptoms, and P-ANCA vasculitis of small vessels usually occurs in older patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP), which is characterized by IgA immune complex deposition. P-ANCA vasculitis affects small vessels but does not typically present with HSP symptoms. Microthrombi could cause a similar presentation but are less likely without other associated symptoms or risk factors. Gram-negative cocci infection could cause abdominal symptoms and high WBC count but would not explain the skin findings or positive stool occult blood test.
